To develop the theory of Hecke operators for FLT I need what I was taught was the second isomorphism theorem, but to my surprise I've discovered that mathlib's statement of the theorem docs#QuotientGroup.quotientInfEquivProdNormalQuotient was strictly weaker than what I was taught as an undergraduate.

Let GGG be a group and let HHH and KKK be subgroups, with no normality assumption on either (this is why my claim below is different to mathlib's). By H/(H∩K)H/(H\cap K)H/(H∩K) I mean the set of left cosets h(H∩K)h(H\cap K)h(H∩K) and by HKHKHK I mean the set of products {hk:h∈H,k∈K}\{hk:h\in H,k\in K\}{hk:h∈H,k∈K} (note that this is not a group in general, if neither HHH nor KKK are normal). This set is easily checked to be a union of left cosets hKhKhK of KKK; by HK/KHK/KHK/K I mean the set of these left cosets. I was taught that the second isomorphism theorem was the canonical bijection H/(H∩K)≅HK/KH/(H\cap K)\cong HK/KH/(H∩K)≅HK/K sending h(H∩K)h(H\cap K)h(H∩K) to hKhKhK. And then the rider is that if KKK happens to be normal then HKHKHK is a subgroup and both the things I'm quotienting out by are normal subgroups and the canonical map unsurprisingly preserves multiplication (which is the statement we have in mathlib).

I realised that I didn't even know how to state the version I need. We have HKHKHK of type Set G as (H : Set G) * (K : Set G) after open scoped Pointwise, but do we even have HK/KHK/KHK/K in any form? The \/ symbol only works for groups and in my application HKHKHK will definitely not be closed under multiplication.

The application is this. Again let HHH and KKK be subgroups of a (infinite, in my case) group GGG (neither of them normal in the application). If GGG acts on an additive abelian group AAA and if g∈Gg\in Gg∈G then under the hypothesis that g−1Hg∩Kg^{-1}Hg\cap Kg−1Hg∩K has finite index in g−1Hgg^{-1}Hgg−1Hg (and in particular the HHH in the previous para is g−1Hgg^{-1}Hgg−1Hg here) I claim that there is a map TgT_gTg​ from AKA^KAK (the KKK-invariant elements of AAA) to AHA^HAH defined by first decomposing HgKHgKHgK as a finite (by an argument which uses my version of the second isomorphism theorem and the fact that g−1HgK/Kg^{-1}HgK/Kg−1HgK/K bijects with HgK/KHgK/KHgK/K) disjoint union giKg_iKgi​K and then sending aaa to ∑igi.a\sum_i g_i.a∑i​gi​.a (which is well-defined and in AHA^HAH if I got all this right; note that it's not yet been formalized). So the #xy of my question is that I want to say "write a subset of GGG which is closed under right multiplication by KKK as a disjoint union of cosets of KKK and choose arbitrary coset representatives" but I would like an idiomatic way to say this if we have such a way (and if not I'll have to make one).
Hmm, I guess I could look at subsets of G/KG/KG/K and G/(H∩K)G/(H\cap K)G/(H∩K), we have these, hopefully we have the GGG-action on them
